#Summary1=(human1) In a letter on July 9, 1951 Zora thanks Jean for some money, shares her progress fixing up her new house in Eau Gallie, Fla., and her neighbors' reactions, details her morning routine, provides updates on her writing and comments on other writers and the Saturday Evening Post before closing with a prayer that she and Jean make a lot of money so that Zora can buy her house.

#Summary2=(claude-3-5-sonnet-20241022) In a 1951 letter, Zora writes to Jean about her happiness in her one-room house in Eau Gallie, Florida, describing her daily activities with birds and gardening, her hopes to purchase the property, and her financial situation, while also mentioning career updates about her writing and plans for a newspaper.

#Summary3=(gpt4o) On July 9, 1951, Zora writes to Jean from her new one-room home in Eau Gallie, Florida, detailing her happiness while improving the property despite financial struggles, expressing hope to purchase it amidst favorable neighborhood sentiments, mentioning her writing progress, and discussing plans for a potential newspaper devoted to domestic service workers.

#Summary4=(Meta-Llama-3-8B-Instruct) Zora Neale Hurston writes to Jean about her new life in Eau Gallie, Florida, where she's bought a one-room house with a large yard and artesian well, and is enjoying a simpler life focused on writing and nature.

#Summary5=(Qwen2.5-7B-Instruct) Zora Neale Hurston writes to Jean about her newfound happiness in her small, improving home in Eau Gallie, Florida, where she plans to settle and possibly purchase the property, while also discussing her writing projects and financial needs.
#Text=Eau Gallie , Fla.
#Text=General Delivery
#Text=July 9 , 1951 .
#Text=Dear Jean :
#Text=Thanks for the money .
#Text=I am fixing up my new home here .
#Text=It is a one - room house , but a large room , and set in two blocks of grounds with an artesian well .
#Text=I have to do some phoneering , but I find that I like it .
#Text=I am the happiest I have been in the last ten years , irregardles of whether Scribners likes the novel or not .
#Text=I am up every morning at five oclock chopping down weeds and planting flowers and things .
#Text=That is why I have been so long getting to my machine to write letters .
#Text=I go to bed happily tired and swear that I will write you a letter first thing in the morning .

#Text=But the birds , which I feed and who have begun to collect here already in large numbers , wake me up clamoring for their breakfast , and I dash out and place stale bread , etc. and watch the many colors and many behaviors of my feathered friends .
#Text=Less than an hour ago , a male cardinal lit on the porch no more than five feet from me and complained that there was no more food outside , so I hurried to put some out .

#Text=Then just as I opened up the machine , a great conclave of birds , led by two crows , screamed to me that some enemy was raiding a mocking - bird nest in a big oak tree , and I rushed over to find a lean and desperate cat climbing the tree , and chunked him clear off the place .
#Text=Spot , and her daughter , Shag , love it here .
#Text=They show it in many ways .
#Text=They go hunting , and so far , have scared up a cat , two rabbits and an armadilla .
#Text=It seems that t ey are plentiful around here .
#Text=From all that hoeing and what not , I am losing weight , God be praised !
#Text=This day , I take out my notes and go back to work with new vigor and a clean - swept mind .
#Text=Two short pieces and back to the attempt at drama .
#Text=I belidve that I can do it , and I 'm giving it a very serious try this time .
#Text=You will have assorted scripts in your hand very shortly .
#Text=Now , you p rhaps questi n why I am putting so much into this place where I now live .
#Text=I have a chance to buy it .
#Text=In this little house I wrote MULES AND MEN .
#Text=Since that time , it has come to be in a White residential neighborhood .
#Text=Eau Gallie has grown with the Jet Base , and not far away , near Cocoa , the Guided Missile Base , and many people stationed here are buying and building .
#Text=Mr. W. Lansing Gleason , my landlord , is the mayor .
#Text=He must go slow about selling it to me , waiting on public reaction .
#Text=It is beginning to be favorable to me .
#Text=Several of my neighbors have stopped in the last week and remarked on the improvements I have made .
#Text=It looked like a jungle three weeks ago , and it took a strong heart and an eye on the future for me to move in when I arrived .
#Text=The place had run down so badly .
#Text=In what was meant to be a compliment , I have been told twice , " You do n't live like the majority of your people . You like things clean and orderly around you . "
#Text=The manager of the local dairy , seeing me setting out flowers as I cleared , surprised me with a load of compost as a present Saturday .
#Text=The grounds have great possibilities , and I really would love to own it .
#Text=I still must remove tons of junk , old tin cans and bottles from the premises .
#Text=Somehow , this one spot on earth feels like home to me .
#Text=I have always intended to come back here .
#Text=That is why I am doing so much to make a go of it .
#Text=No house in a block of me four ways .
#Text=No loud radios and record - playing to irritate me , and great oaks and palms around the place .
#Text=I do hope that other person that Burroughs Mitchell had reading my script was not Roy Ottley .
#Text=You can see why I would not want a Negro writer to be handling it .
#Text=Since none of the others have thought to do anything with the hair - traightening business , it might prove a temptation to play my work down to Burroughs , then do something on it himself .
#Text=Please check on that for me .
#Text=The Saturday Evening Post photographer has been here and took a lot of pictures .
#Text=He caught me in my dungarees working outdoors , and naturally insisted on photographing me like that .
#Text=He told me that Ben Hibbs likes the article very much and it will be in an early issue .
#Text=I gather from reading the magazine that the SEP favors Taft , and so it probably falls right in with the plan .
#Text=They never se m to miss a chance recently to mention him favorably .
#Text=As soon as I can get some things in your hands to sell , I shall try to raise the cash for my newspaper devoted to those in domestic service .
#Text=I really believe that the idea is sound and can makke money . [ ... ]

#Text=I paid up my sick and accident insurance for a year , $ 67.70 , and spent so much getting the house wired and made more livable in other ways around the place , that I am almost broke already again .
#Text=Bought an ice - box , and furniture too , so now , as badly as I hate to draw it , I need some cash to live on .
#Text=For groceries and gas .
#Text=And a pair of black slacks so that I can go downtown without messing up another was dress which takes up my time to launder .
#Text=My best to you and yours , and pray that we make a lot of money this year , so that when / if I am told that I can buy this place , I can do it and build a comfortable little new house on it .
#Text=Love and faithful feelings ,
#Text=Zora
